IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Elderhostel sponsors, arranges or conducts educational programs around the world primarily for adults age 55 and older.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Elderhostel, Inc. is a not-for-profit organization incorporated in December 1977 for the purpose of sponsoring, arranging or conducting educational programs primarily for adults age 55 and older. Programs are marketed under the Elderhostel and Road Scholar trade names. Its mission is to empower adults through learning. Elderhostel's mission is based on the knowledge that learning is an integral part of healthy aging, and that sharing new ideas, and encountering new challenges, perspectives and experiences, is rewarding in every season of life. Elderhostel enrolled nearly 97,700 participants in over 4,300 programs throughout the United States, Canada and more than 90 other countries. Elderhostel publishes comprehensive program catalogs, provides extensive information on the Web, and provides a registration system to match interested participants with available programs.
IRS990.Description: 76,579 enrollees participated in Elderhostel's unique liberal arts educational programs in the United States and Canada (ranging in length from one day to three weeks). These programs provide a stimulating academic experience exploring the arts, literature, sciences, history, culture, and environment of North America. Some programs provide community service and others are designed to be multi-generational, allowing a grandchild, or adult children and their children, to attend. Room and board are included in the cost of United States and Canada programs.

Activity2.Description: 11,785 enrollees participated in Elderhostel's educational programs held outside the United States (ranging in length from one week to four weeks). These programs provide a stimulating academic experience introducing participants to the arts, history, literature, culture, architecture and natural environment of their locations. They are designed to further cross-cultural understanding by forging direct connections between participants and local residents, experts and lecturers. Community service and multi-generational programs are also offered. Room, board and in most cases airfare are included in the cost of programs held outside the United States.

Activity3.Description: 4,774 enrollees participated in Elderhostel's Adventures Afloat programs (ranging in length from one week to three months). These programs are ship-based learning adventures that allow participants to experience the educational wonders of broad regions interconnected by the world's oceans and waterways. Experts and professors provide a rigorous educational program on board, which is enhanced by fieldtrips to experience the culture of local communities through related land components and lectures. See comments above regarding the inclusion of room, board and airfare.

ActivityOther.Description: 4,554 enrollees participated in Elderhostel's Day of Discovery programs which are unique one-day learning explorations in cities across the United States intended for participants who are seeking an Elderhostel experience closer to home or with a shorter time frame. Elderhostel also operates these programs in continuing care retirement communities to benefit residents who may no longer be able to travel.

6.3 million catalogs & smaller publications were produced and mailed to over 429,000 households on Elderhostel's mailing list. The website, which provides program information, had at least 21 million page views from over 1.5 million unique visitors.

Eighty six staff in eight offices in the United States and United Kingdom worked with over 1,000 providers and vendors to develop, operate, oversee and evaluate nearly 2,500 unique programs with more than 4,300 departure dates.

Our 48 seat Participant Service Center located in Massachusetts handled over 239,000 telephone calls from inquirers and enrollees that resulted in over 90,000 enrollment, cancellation, transfer and contribution transactions. In addition, our nine seat Travel Service Center located in Vermont handled over 50,000 telephone calls from participants who desired assistance in making their travel arrangements to Elderhostel programs.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Elderhostel's endowment includes 18 donor-restricted funds established primarily to provide scholarships and a Board-designated fund to provide operating support.
Elderhostel accounts for tax contigencies in accordance with ASC 740, Income Taxes, and has no uncertain tax positions at September 30, 2010.

Form990ScheduleIPartIII.TypeOfGrant: Dr. Asa Grant Hilliard III Educational Grant to an African American educator
Elderhostel K. Patricia Cross Doctoral Research Grant

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Elderhostel posts awarded scholarships as credits to recipients' accounts which can be applied by recipients against the cost of Elderhostel programs in the U.S. Scholarships are never paid in cash and expire if they are not used. Elderhostel posts the Asa Grant Hilliard III Award for Lifelong Learning as a credit to the recipient's account so that it may be applied by the recipient against the cost of one or more Elderhostel programs. The Asa Grant Hilliard III Award for Lifelong Learning is never paid in cash and it expires if it is not used by the recipient. Elderhostel requests that the recipient of the Elderhostel K. Patricia Cross Doctoral Research Grant provide a copy of his or her research or dissertation and a report on how the grant proceeds were utilized in completing or publishing that research or dissertation.

As part of a continuing mission to ensure that its educational programs are widely accessible to older adults, Elderhostel provides scholarships on a nondiscriminatory basis to those who demonstrate financial need. By increasing the economic diversity of participants, scholarships help enrich the Elderhostel experience for all who take part in our programs. Qualified applicants are entitled to one scholarship per calendar year. Scholarships may be up to $800 per grant and are provided for enrollment in programs in the United States.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Column B (iii) labeled 'Other reportable compensation' is compensation deferred by employees into the Elderhostel, Inc 457(b) plan.

Form990ScheduleKPartI.DescriptionOfPurpose: Reissuance of bonds issued in 2000. See Schedule O for more explanation.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is reviewed by the Audit Committee and the Board of Directors before it is filed.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Elderhostel has a Conflict of Interest Policy to govern arrangements and activities between Elderhostel's Board of Directors and key employees and other "Interested Persons" as defined in the policy. The policy details the duty to disclose conflicts of interest, procedures for addressing any conflict, and defines and identifies possible conflicts of interest. Annually, all directors and key employees sign a statement which affirms their understanding of the policy and disclose any potential conflicts of interest. All disclosed conflicts are reviewed with the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Compensation of the President/CEO and other senior employees is reviewed annually by the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors against compensation surveys available from various sources. These surveys assist the Board in ensuring that Elderhostel management's compensation is comparable with other not-for-profit organizations of similar size (in terms of revenue, assets, or number of employees). The deliberation and decisions regarding compensation arrangements are contemporaneously documented and recorded in the minutes of the Executive Committee. The compensation review process has been conducted annually since 2002.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Elderhostel provides its governing documents, Conflict of Interest Policy and Audited Financial Statements upon request in either print or electronic form.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VII, Section B, Line 1(A)
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The top five independent contractors reported on the Form 990 are program providers. Payments to these providers are shown on a gross basis for the calendar year 2009. A substantial portion of the payment is for costs incurred by the provider in arranging and conducting Elderhostel programs including accommodations, transportation, and meals for program participants, which Elderhostel cannot segregate. The top five independent contractors that are not program providers are as follows: Graphic Communications (printing and mailing catalogs and brochures) - $1,400,501; CSG Systems Inc. (database maintenance) - $282,687; Perrone Group (printing and mailing brochures and fundraising materials) - $260,522; Trend Ofset Printing Inc. (printing and mailing brochures) - $158,429; and Walsworth Publishing Co Inc. (printing and mailing catalogs) - $ 134,436.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Schedule K, Part I, Column f
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: This is a reissuance of bonds previously issued on January 27, 2000 for the acquisition and renovation of the organization's headquarters building in Boston.

On April 1, 2008, Elderhostel purchased Lyon Travel Agency, Inc. and merged it into a wholly-owned limited liability subsidiary, ETS LLC. In July 2010, Elderhostel dissolved the subsidiary. Elderhostel acquired the assets, assumed the liabilities and hired the employees of the subsidiary. The airline ticketing and other travel services previously provided by the subsidiary to participants attending Elderhostel's programs are now performed by Elderhostel.

Form990ScheduleRPartI.PrimaryActivities: Airline ticketing and other travel services, primarily as part of Elderhostel's educational programs
